this episode I'm going to do the complete opposite and throw my own
advice out the window because I want to make a ruined tower
and this is one of the times where I think it's okay to not be modular and
the reason for that is a round Tower is a very specific item I don't need many
many different setups of round towers usually there's only gonna be one of
them in an encounter so I figured it was okay to make a dedicated building in
this circumstance because also I don't want to make modular around the walls
that's kind of a pain in the ass so this week I am going to build a ruined Tower
I'm going to do it in such a way that it is going to be very playable it's big

if I ever really want to just have a normal Tower I just spin this thing

maybe now's the time let build a badass-looking ruined tower I started
this project by making a metric but ton of little bricks and I did this using
the same method that I did in my modular ruins video so if you haven't seen that
one yet head on over and check that one out to see the whole process of making
these little bricks using some half-inch XPS insulation foam and my procs on hot
wire table and the circle cutting jig from chipping lands calm I created a
base from this tower I wanted a large solid circle on which I could build
these circular walls how big is this circle I don't know I don't remember it
was as big as I could get out of this scrap piece of foam using that circle as
a guide I started to construct my walls I just attached my bricks using hot glue
I did a double layer wall and started building up the sections also once I got
to the fourth row I kept something in mind that a viewer mentioned on my
previous ruins video and that is that on brick walls like this there should be a
course of bricks that runs the other direction to tie them together and that
makes a lot of sense so I figured hey why not do that here make it more
realistic I realized that doing this on a circle was probably not the best place
to do it for the first time because it created a lot of kind of crappy gaps and
whatever but hey here's one kind of realistic course of bricks to tie them
together I gave up and didn't do any more later in the build once the walls
got to the height of what would be appropriate for the second story I put
in some wooden joists using coffee stir sticks doing it at this point now was a
lot easier than doing it later I could just cut a little groove in the bricks
and glue the stir sticks in place and this would make them really strong and
they would be there and ready for when I wanted
put on the wood plank floor later then I continue to build the walls and at this
height is where I put the arrow slits because the whole point of this tower
was playability so it was it really important to me that there was a place
that enemies could fire from so to make the arrow slits I just did something
really easy which was create some square cubes I then cut them into little
triangular pieces and glued them in place so what this did was create a
small slit on the exterior of the tower and a wider opening on the interior of
the tower for the archer to stand then with those in place I infilled the
bricks between them after doing some testing with a mini I realized these
needed to be taller so I made them two of these wedges high and they created
the perfect arrow slits I capped off the tops of these with one solid brick so
there wasn't a mortar joint right above the opening and then I continued
building my walls I didn't really like how some of the really big gaps in the
brickwork looked so I filled some of them in using some tiny wedges of foam
not all of them just the worst offenders it was then time to start decorating the
floor and I wanted a kind of more interesting pattern than just one-inch
squares so I cut some tiny little bricks some of these being true squares and
some of them being rectangles I coated the entire bottom of the foam using
Eileen's tacky glue and then I started laying flooring in my pattern of choice
I didn't worry much about getting it perfect around the perimeter because I
knew that I would be covering this with rubble and in fact some of the worst
spots I just covered with a couple extra fallen bricks
I wanted the floor to be totally blown out on the back end of this thing so I
marked out the shape that I wanted and I took the whole thing to my procs on and
I just hacked out a big chunk of the floor using the hot wire which was very
oddly satisfying because I wanted the base to look like it was blown up stone
or concrete the smooth hot wire cut wasn't entirely appropriate so using a
knife and my fingernail I just kind of ripped out tiny pieces of the foam to
give it a more crumbled stone look to hide the circular base I cut some larger
foundation stones and glued them around the edge using my exacto knife I kind of
chamfered all the edges to give them a slightly more weathered look I wanted to
add a little bit more visual interest to this thing so I made some decorative
features using various strips of foam then I decided to test something that
was quite risky to do I'm never a fan of how hot glue leaves little wisps all
over a project and I know that one of the ways you can get rid of this is by
using a heat gun however a heat gun will also melt and deform styrofoam so I
decided that I would take my heat gun to this piece melt away the wisps and try
to sort of control melt all the bricks to weather them even further you have to
be incredibly careful doing this because in just a matter of seconds
your bricks will go from slightly deformed to totally melted away there's
a bizarrely specific breaking point on the temperature where it goes from zero
to a hundred so you have to use a lot of caution the nice thing about this is
that afterwards all this foam is cauterized and very very hard again I
wasn't happy with how large some of the gaps were on the foundation stones and
the decorative ador that I added so I filled those in using
a sort of mortar that I made out of watered-down joint compound I just
forced some of this into the cracks and using a wet brush wiped away all the
excess if you're gonna do this you have to be careful to try and do a really
neat and clean job so that it doesn't look like everything is just covered in
mud in order to complete the ruined look I use some construction sand to kind of
decorate all of the edges of this piece just use some PVA glue and sprinkled on
the sand in order to look like rubble and hide any more gaps that might be
showing where the floor meets the walls then it was time for painting and before
I paint any of my projects I always prep them using Mod Podge and black paint
this acts as a hardening coat as well as a sort of primer and it will protect the
foam for years to come to paint this thing I did the exact same paint job I
did on my modular ruined set because I wanted them to match and that was just a
base coat in a dark grey and then a dry brushing with a light tan and a final
dry brushing of a white then I gave the whole piece a coating in a very dark
blackish-brown wash I put that aside to dry and got to work on the wood planks
for the floor yes I have not forgotten about those to make these I use some
coffee stir sticks and I weathered them and kind of shaped them the same way I
did in my goblin barricades video using a rotary tool I beveled the edges and
made them look well not like coffee stir sticks then I pre painted all of the
wood stir sticks using a really watered-down Brown once they were dry I
could start installing them and I actually wanted to add one more joist so
that I could make the floor a little bit bigger but this was one that I didn't
want to span all the way across so I just cut a little groove using my exacto
knife in the bricks used a bit of glue and poked the coffee stirrer into the
wall and it held surprisingly strong I could then cut my stir sticks to length
and start installing them I just put a bead of PVA glue down on the joist cut
my pieces to length and put them in place on the ends that were exposed I
broke them so that they had a kind of destroyed look to them and they didn't
look like clean cuts once all of the planks were in place I gave them the
same dark brown black wash that I gave on the rest of the piece and you can see
here that I also had added some broken pieces of timber on the main floor the
last painting step was to give the whole thing a very light dry brushing using
the same light tan that I had used previously
and I went over everything here I went over all of the stonework as well as the
wood and on the wood this light tan made the wood look a lot more aged and
weathered giving it that nice little gray touch after that I took the piece
outside and I gave it a spray with Minwax polyurethane in a satin finish
this is my go-to clear coat for terrain it locks in all of the paint makes the
foam a little bit harder and I find that it kind of enhances the color in a way
that I like I really like the way this project came out and I think it will
complement my modular ruin set very nicely it's nice when you have a bit of
terrain that is very playable in the sense that it can actually add dynamic
interaction to an encounter there's some high ground there's some cover and that
can be really fun to use as a DM but more importantly it's going to be really
fun for your players to play on if you need to pick up any of the tools or
